questions.description: Existing JavaScript code is syntactically valid TypeScript code
questions.explanation: TypeScript is a super set of JavaScript, meaning all JavaScript is valid TypeScript. In this case, the types get inferred to be any.

questions.description: When does TypeScript validate & return errors based on the defined types in your code?
questions.explanation: It happens when you run the TypeScript compiler, allowing you to see any bugs before your code even hits the browser.

choices.value: When you run the code in the browser
When you deploy the code to production
When you run the TypeScript compiler
When you run a unit test on that section of the code

questions.description: What type would foo be defined as? ` let foo; foo = â€˜bar'`
questions.explanation: foo would be defined as any as the default value, unless specifically limited to a string by the developer.

questions.description: What do TypeScript Generics allow you to do with a function?
questions.explanation: Generics allow for TS functions to be more generic, where the developer can use the function to perform operations on the type of their choosing.

choices.value: Make the type definition more strict
Extend a function to be more reusable by work with multiple types
